docs.lead_paragraph: Federal investigators widened their search of medical offices around El Paso yesterday, seizing documents from doctors affiliated with the local hospitals operated by the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, people familiar with the situation said. The action came in the second day of the Government's search, which was now said to be completed. On Wednesday, investigators from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Internal Revenue Service and the Department of Health and Human Services served search warrants on a series of Columbia facilities in El Paso, as well as on dozens of doctors.

headline.main: U.S. Expands Search of Columbia/HCA in Texas

docs.abstract: Federal investigators widen search of Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, seizing documents from doctors in El Paso area who are affiliated with its local hospitals; search warrants have been issued by Federal Bureau of Investigation, Internal Revenue Service and Dept of Health and Human Services; Defense Dept's Criminal Investigation Service has also reportedly joined inquiry; Government has not disclosed nature of probe, but agencies involved indicate that focus may be on Government health care payment programs such as Medicare, Medicaid and Champus, insurance program for military personnel; Columbia says it believes investigation is limited to El Paso, but law enforcement officials say privately that probe is proceeding in other cities where Columbia does business (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Employers should not be allowed to use genetic tests to discriminate on the job, deny health insurance or violate employee privacy, geneticists, ethicists and health advocates said today. The group, which includes Francis Collins, director of the National Human Genome Research Institute at the National Institutes of Health, made the recommendations in an essay being published on Friday in the journal Science. They said an employer's access to information about a worker's genetics should be restricted, and the worker protected from job discrimination, by uniform nationwide laws or regulations.

headline.main: Ban Sought on Employers' Use of Gene Tests

docs.abstract: Essay by group of geneticists, ethicists and health advocates published in March 21 journal Science contends that employers should not be allowed to use genetic tests to discriminate on job, deny health insurance or violate employee privacy (S)
docs.snippet: Employers should not be allowed to use genetic tests to discriminate on the job, deny health insurance or violate employee privacy, geneticists, ethicists and health advocates said today.     The group, which includes Francis Collins, director of the...

docs.lead_paragraph: KENNEDY-Henry M. March 14, 1997. Of Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, N.J. Husband of the late Mary Bingham Kennedy. He graduated from Kent School in 1928 and Princeton University in 1932. He is survived by two sons Henry M. Jr of Ridgewood, N.J. and Bingham of McLean, Va. and 5 grandchildren. A past Vice President of the Prudential Insurance Company, he served as President of the Life Advertisers Association and as a Director of the Association of National Advertisers. His interest in health care lead to his serving as the first Chairman of the New Jersey State Health Planning Council, as well as other regional councils. He served as a trustee of the Hospital Center at Orange Foundation. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Presbyterian Homes Foundation, P.O. Box 2184, Princeton, N.J. 08543.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, HENRY M.

docs.lead_paragraph: Elderly people in health maintenance organizations often find that they cannot obtain the medical services they need because H.M.O.'s limit their ability to appeal adverse decisions on treatment, Federal investigators said today. June Gibbs Brown, inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services, said that many Medicare beneficiaries were never informed of their appeal rights. And Ms. Brown said that many H.M.O.'s -- more than half of those examined by Federal auditors -- did not fully comply with Federal rules for handling appeals and grievances.

headline.main: H.M.O.'S LIMITING MEDICARE APPEALS, U.S. INQUIRY FINDS

docs.abstract: Federal investigators say elderly people in health maintenance organizations are often unable to obtain medical services they need because HMO's limit their ability to appeal adverse decisions on treatment; Health Department inspector general June Gibbs Brown says many Medicare beneficiaries are never informed of their appeal rights, and that many HMO's do not fully comply with Federal rules for handling appeals and grievances; findings of Medicare probe into HMO's handling of appeals and grievances discussed; five million of 38 million Medicare beneficiaries are currently enrolled in HMO's and enrollment is growing by more than 80,000 per month; Congressional Budget Office predicts more than 15 million Medicare beneficiaries will be enrolled by 2007 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York said yesterday that it had placed in review the account of its consolidated insurance plans, which has been divided among several agencies on a regional basis. Estimated combined billings could reach as much as $15 million.

docs.lead_paragraph: His wife will not kiss him. His daughter-in-law shrieked in terror when he cut himself shaving and one of her children touched his cheek. He is 72 years old, infected with AIDS from a blood transfusion during a 1980 heart bypass. All he wants of the life left to him is to attend his 8-year-old granddaughter's bat mitzvah and his 6-year-old grandson's first Little League game.

headline.main: Five Brief Histories of Pain, Guilt and Many Other Emotions

docs.abstract: Five AIDS victims over age of 50 tell their sad stories; photo (M)

Following are a baker's dozen that may escape Federal income tax. * Certain prizes and awards for outstanding educational activities, literary or civic achievements.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Hello, Missy, welcome to the White House,'' Bill Clinton tells a terminally ill child visiting him in the Oval Office. ''I understand you haven't been feeling too well.'' In the background, Missy's parents are beaming, especially her father, who lost his job because he was busy caring for his daughter. In Congress, Senator Edward M. Kennedy begins a committee hearing on a related issue, children's health care. He speaks eloquently about the 10 million children of hard-working families without health insurance, children who suffer recurring illnesses without ever seeing doctors. ''Do we have the political will to provide health care for those 10 million?'' he asks. It's a powerful statement until he adds: ''We welcome our first witness. Mr. Wilmette, Chicago Hope Hospital.''

headline.main: The Politics of Paying A Visit to Prime Time

docs.abstract: Caryn James comment on fast-growing trend toward politicians making appearances playing selves on television entertainment programs to advance their social policy messages; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS he recuperated from kidney surgery last March, Richard A. Lundwall stared at the walls of his hospital room and stewed about how he was being treated by his longtime employer, Texaco Inc. Weeks before, Mr. Lundwall had been unceremoniously forced out of his job in Texaco's finance department. Most colleagues ignored him; no one offered an official farewell on his last day. Mr. Lundwall even felt slighted by the company's failure to send a personal note during his stay at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut.

headline.main: Blowing the Whistle, and Now Facing the Music

docs.abstract: Interviews with Richard A Lundwall, dismissed Texaco Inc aide who made public tapes of Texaco executives belittling minorities and plotting destruction of documents sought in discrimination suit; Lundwall, indicted for role in destroying documents, discusses negative impact of disclosure on his life and his reasons for recording, keeping and belatedly disclosing tapes; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: CONNECTICUT is coming late to the table of deregulation concerning the electric utility industry within its borders. But, though the issue may not spark wild enthusiasm among most state residents, legislation now under consideration could have a profound impact on consumers' wallets, as well as the state's environmental quality. Electric rates in the state are 35 percent higher than the national average. The question is whether restructuring of the industry will wind up costing the customer more or less than the current system. It depends entirely on the details of legislation now under consideration in the state.

headline.main: Will Electric Bills Go Up or Down?

docs.abstract: Electric rates in Connecticut are 35 percent higher than national average; deregulation legislation now under consideration could have profound impact on consumers' electric bills; photos (M)
